On Sat, 2004-05-29 at 01:55, bruce wrote:
> in regards to my last message, we're starting to climb through the docs for
> heritrix.. we don't initially see anything that jumps out at us as to how
> the app handles, or can be configured to handle parsing through
> dropdown/select menu structures within a given page...

If the URL is visible in the HTML source, Heritrix will find it (and
then apply its rules as to whether to follow it or not).  If it is not,
as is frequently the case with Javascript-based menus, Heritrix stands
little chance of finding out right now.

Storing and re-running the Javascript itself is not a problem, the
problem is to make sure you get the URLs it refers to.  Two possible
solutions we have considered are

1) Run the page through an actual browser that allows crawling the DOM
and grab all the URLs encountered.  That'd find those URLs that are
created at page loading time, but not such as are created due to user
actions.  Not too hard to do, if you can find a browser that interacts
well.  Probably very CPU-consuming, though.

2) Make a partial evaluator that attempts to decide what URLs can be
created in Javascript.  Most Javascript code I've looked at is fairly
regular and would be highly amenable to partial evaluation. This would
be a major undertaking, and would also require something that
understands the DOM.  We've considered passing this off to students as a
masters or Ph.D. project, we certainly don't have the resources
ourselves.  

3) Do a manual quality check with a proxy server that notices the URLs
clicked but not found.  This sounds like a lot of work, but with a
limited number of sites it can get big improvements in the workings of
the archived copy, as typically only a few essential menu URLs are
missing.

-Lars
